subject: Ethics
title: The Trolley Problem
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The Trolley Problem.

hook.text: A trolley is about to kill five people. You can pull a lever to divert it‚Äîbut it will kill one person instead.

buildup.text: Philosopher Philippa Foot invented this dilemma in 1967 to test whether outcomes or actions matter more.

discovery.text: Most people pull the lever. Five lives saved for one lost feels like simple math.

twist.text: Now change it: you must push a man off a bridge to stop the trolley. Same math. Most people refuse.

climax.text: The difference reveals something deep‚Äîwe judge actions by how they feel, not just by their results.

punchline.text: Same outcome, different action. That's why ethics is hard.

quiz.question: What does the trolley problem reveal about how people make moral judgments?
options: People always choose to save the most lives regardless of the method
People judge actions by how they feel, not just by their outcomes
People refuse to make any choice when lives are at stake
